senses.de: To state or show that a fact is true.
senses.ex: The doctor can do a test to confirm you are not sick.

Tips.title: Proof Required
Tips.description: Use 'confirm' to talk about showing evidence or proof that something is true.
Tips.example: The email you received confirms your concert tickets are booked.

Tips.title: No Doubt Left
Tips.description: 'Confirm' suggests eliminating any doubt about a fact or information.
Tips.example: This signature confirms the authenticity of the document.

senses.ex: Please confirm your attendance at the meeting.

Tips.title: Finalize Plans
Tips.description: 'Confirm' often indicates making plans definite or official.
Tips.example: I will confirm the venue for our meeting tomorrow.

Tips.title: Pre-event Usage
Tips.description: Use 'confirm' before an event, to ensure arrangements are made.
Tips.example: Can you confirm your hotel check-in date?

senses.de: To give approval to something, especially by saying it is correct.
senses.ex: The manager needs to confirm your report before it can be sent.

Tips.title: Formal Endorsement
Tips.description: 'Confirm' can imply formal or official approval of something.
Tips.example: The board will confirm the new policy next week.

Tips.title: Last Step
Tips.description: It's often the last step before an action can proceed.
Tips.example: You need to confirm receipt of the package to start the return process.

senses.de: In a religious context, it means to make a Christian baptism complete by confirming faith in God.
senses.ex: The bishop will confirm the new believers in the church.

Tips.title: Spiritual Commitment
Tips.description: In religion, 'confirm' indicates a commitment to faith.
Tips.example: After being baptized, he will be confirmed at Easter.

Tips.title: Ritual Importance
Tips.description: The use of 'confirm' implies a significant religious ceremony or ritual.
Tips.example: Her family attended her confirmation ceremony.

Affirm.wordDefinition:
Affirm means to state positively or to declare to be true.

It is used to express agreement or support for something. For example, you might affirm your belief in a certain political party or affirm your commitment to a relationship.

The main difference between these two words is that affirm is used to declare support or belief in something while confirm is used to verify or establish the truth of something.

Approve.wordDefinition:
Approve means to give permission or agreement to something. For example, a teacher could approve a student's project proposal.

Alternatively, a boss could approve an employee's leave of absence request.

So, in brief, approve is about giving permission or agreement, while confirm is about verifying the truth or accuracy of something.

Assert.wordDefinition:
Assert means to state or declare something confidently, typically without providing any proof or evidence. It is applicable when you are expressing your opinion or belief.

For example, if you say, "I assert that pineapple does not belong on pizza," you are expressing your opinion. But if someone says, "Can you confirm if the sun is a star?" you are being asked to verify a fact.

Certify.wordDefinition:
Certify means to officially verify or attest to something through an official process or documentation. For example, a document can be certified by a notary public, meaning the notary has verified that the document is genuine.

It can be used in a broader sense than certify, and does not necessarily involve an official process or documentation.

Certify is used in more formal, official contexts, while confirm can be used in a wider range of situations.

Endorse.wordDefinition:
Endorse means to express support or approval of something or someone. For example, if you endorse a product, you are saying that you like it and think that others should use it too.

Endorse is usually used when there is a positive opinion or feeling towards something, and it is being recommended to others.

Confirm is used to make sure something is true, while endorse is used to express support or approval of something.

Ratify.wordDefinition:
Ratify means to give formal approval to something that has been negotiated or agreed upon. This typically refers to a more significant or legally binding agreement, such as a treaty or a contract.

To put it simply, confirming is like double-checking something that's already been decided, while ratifying is like officially approving something that's still being negotiated.

Support.wordDefinition:
Support means to provide assistance or help to something or someone.

If a student wants to help a friend who is struggling with the same math problem, they can offer to support their friend by explaining the concept or working through the problem together.

Confirm is used when you want to make sure something is true or correct, while support is used when you want to help something or someone.

Validate.wordDefinition:
Validate means to evaluate, authenticate, or give official approval or recognition to something. For example, if a scientist performs an experiment, they may need to validate their results with other scientists or through additional experiments to ensure their findings are accurate and reliable.

Confirm is used to ensure that something is correct or true, while validate is used to give official approval or recognition to something or make sure it is reliable or accurate.

Verify.wordDefinition:
The main difference between the words confirm and verify is that confirm means to make sure something that you already know is true or to agree with something that someone else has said or told you.

Verify means to check if something is true or correct. For example, if you receive an email from your bank asking you to verify your identity by answering some security questions, you might need to confirm your name, address, and date of birth to prove that it's really you.

To sum up, confirm is used when you already know something and want to make it certain, while verify is used when you need to check if something is true or correct.
